comments.body:
It occurs to me that there is a latent endian-ness bug here. If you were to use this code on a big-endian architecture, the layout of the encoded bytes would not match the byte layout in memory.

Not sure what to do here. I suspect for now, leave a // TODO: add big-endian support and move on.

I suspect to fix this right, we should add logic to perform byteswapping on serialization or deserialization of a half literal.

or better still, add a 16 bit uint support in protobuf (or even a 16 bit float support in protobuf).  I decided to open an Issue with Protobuf:
https://github.com/google/protobuf/issues/3091
it's only a problem if the literals are sent over the network of course.  Is that ever true?

Literals are certainly stored on disk. I don't know whether you have discovered them, but you can dump computations to disk (TF_XLA_FLAGS=--xla_dump_computations_to=/tmp/somewhere) and there are utilities to visualize and replay dumped computations in tensorflow/compiler/xla/tools. So the potential for the problem is there, at least --- you can copy the dumped computations between machines.

I agree that it would be nice if protobuf added a 16-bit type, but it won't happen immediately even if they agree.
